title: World Chess Hall of Fame, Saint Louis
review_list:
Gift shop was good and cashier was very helpful. The first floor exhibit was a nice art display but not for younger kids. Second floor had a display in conjunction with the Magic House. It had a large chess board but someone was already playing so we missed out. Third floor was the actual HOF. Boring for my son.

Went with 7 yr old who is interested in chess and we loved the exhibit on the second floor Kings Queens and Castles. Giant chessboard and activities for young kids interested in game. WW2 exhibit very interesting. Everything nicely presented and nice staff.

I have been there last weekend...Its a good place for Chess lovers...Staff is supporive and Nice...As an Indian i was expecting vishvanath Anand Pic too on th HOF

We attended a "chamber music" concert at the World Chess Hall of Fame. In the process we were able to appreciate the entire museum.
I had been there a few years ago, today it is an attractive combination of exhibits, art, education and entertainment. I'm not sure many people will view this small museum as a destination, but this should...


More  



See chess sets from all eras and all countries in this out of the way museum in St. Louis. Exhibitions include the US and World Chess Hall of Fame plaques. And it's free. Go for a taste of something different.

Didn't get a chance to experience the whole museum since the third floor was closed for a special event. The first floor had a really neat art exhibit by women artists of chess related pieces. Probably would have been better if I got to see the whole museum.

I don't play chess and still found the exhibits interesting. The museum has a small footprint but there are three floors packed with things to look at.
Free parking will probably be hard to get so plan on getting a metered space on the cross street. At least on a weekday they were readily available.
The neighborhood has lots of...


More  



We are not big chess players but still enjoyed the visit. The building is very nice and the displays are very well done. It's nice that it was no charge and there are many things to do in the same area.

My son is 9 and loves chess so we had to make a stop here and I'm glad we did. There are basically 3 rooms full of exhibits. My son is not museum material but because of the chess connection he had a good time.
I especially loved the various types of chess boards, especially the one made in Alaska....


More  



Very easy to miss this place and not know it is there. Buried in the middle of town. But be sure to stop and see the Chess Hall of Fame if you were a fan of the game. Great old building/house too. Can't miss the giant king standing in front of it.

title: Moto Museum, Saint Louis
review_list:
Free entrance. If you are a motorcycle buff, you can definitely enjoy a tour of the museum. Good collection of a variety of motorcycles. I loved the scooter collection. Walk into all the rooms and enjoy a quick drink at the connected bar.

This is a free museum of very unusual motorcycles from around the world. Most of them are very old, but in good shape. Each one is identified.

We stumbled on this place while waiting for Samuel Cupples house to open & touring SLU campus. A very nice collection of well restored European motorcycles

Found the collection most interesting and rare. A fine addition to the fantastic fare at the eatery and the way cool hotel plus the dealership for Triumph, Ducati and Vespa's.

I loved it! It's also a great space for events! There are a lot of motorcycles in here event from other countries. It's a very nice place!

A little of the beaten path, but this gem of a find is a must visit when heading to St. Louis. The museum has a wide variety of motorcycles that from around the world. The Triumph Grill that was attached had an amazing atmosphere, with a unique decor and the food while little in price was huge in taste! I...


More  



The museum is the cornerstone to a whole motorcycle city block. The Triumph cafe adjoins the museum. There is also a Ducati, Triumph and KTM dealership. I was let into the museum after hours while eating at the very delicious Triumph cafe.

Had a business Christmas party here and we had a wonderful time. The motorcycles everywhere are crazy old and just awesome. This would be a great place for a wedding reception. The atmosphere in the banquet area is perfect. Go check this place out!

It's a museum, Ducati dealership and restaurant. The collection of motorcycles from countries you never knew made motorcycles is amazing - not one Japanese bike in the place. Admission is free, but please leave a donation when you go. Take your time looking around - it's worth it!

I visited the museum when some visitors from Taiwan came with their 3 boys. I thought I would be bored... this museum is amazing and so interesting! We spent several hours looking at all the motorcycles. It is hard to believe that this collection belongs to one ST Louis based gentleman.
Impressive and fascinating history and evolution of the cycle....


More

title: Pulitzer Arts Foundation, Saint Louis
review_list:
Not sure why, this museum is not one of my favorites. Big concrete building, doesn't have much character in my opinion, and the exhibits in the lower level are claustrophobic. Looking at other reviews, I see many people love it so for some reason it is not resonating with me.

Such a spectacular architectural jewel provided a stunning setting for beautifully curated exhibitions of Calder, Tuttle and Sandback exhibitions. A must see! And admission is free.

The Calder exhibit brought us to St. Louis and it didn't disappoint. It looked so at home in this amazing art space. We visited with our kids (7and 9) and found the staff welcoming and helpful. We had missed the tour, but got lots of stories and tidbits of information from the staff scattered throughout the exhibit halls. Yes, they...


More  



So impressive! This strikingly gorgeous modern building adds to the beauty of the art on display here without detracting from it. Friendly, knowledgeable docents are present in every room to answer questions and add to your viewing experience. Don't miss the Richard Serra sculpture in the courtyard!

The only negative is the limited hours -- Wed-Sat. If you hate the current exhibition, the architecture and three permanent pieces will enchant you -- Blue Black by Ellsworth Kelly, a stone bench by the pool and Joe by Richard Serra. The architecture of the building is worth the trip. The architect, Tadao Ando, won the Pritzker during his short...


More  



This is one of those museums that leave you feeling refreshed after your visit. You know that wiped out, if-I-see-another-work-by-DaVinci-I'm-going-to-scream feeling that the Louvre gives you? You don't get that here.
Andao designed a beautiful little nook here in St Louis where you can see several pieces of art, and then remember what you saw when you left.
And it's...


More  



Just happened to be walking by and popped in. Calder's mobiles looked great in the space; a blend of natural and artificial light bouncing off the walls of varying heights. The Tuttle and Sandback pieces were fun/made funny, mainly because we were the only ones in there at the time and we bantered a lot with the staff. When a...


More  



We visited on a Friday morning and literally had the entire museum to ourselves. I'm not sure why there aren't large crowds given the excellent show of three artists, Calder being the best known. The museum "guards" are also curators and demonstrate great knowledge of the art. Don't miss the Serra in the courtyard.

The only thing that could make the Pulitzer Foundation better would be for them to be open longer. They're currently only open Wednesday and Saturday afternoons. It is, however, free and it's a gem. Any city in the US would be proud to have such a gorgeous building by a such a world renowned architect (Tadao Ando), that puts on...


More  



While the Pulitzer museum is open only at special times, I find it facinating. The Ellsworth Kelly wall sculpture "Blue Black"provides a striking and wonderful wall some 150 feet(?) in the distance and Richard Serra’s "Joe" is one of his best. The raised floor level water pond provides a serenity which could be viewed for hours.
Don't miss this gem.

Was very impressed with the facility , Was clean easy layout. Parking was not too far away and was well maintained. I've been to several basketball games and a concert here and I must say this is a nice, not overly large venue. All seats are good, and parking is plentiful. There is good access to I-44 so you can get in and out pretty easy.

1ST time ever seeing a concert here & it was an excellent venue. A smaller venue so not a bad seat in the house. Sound quality was good & parking around the venue was fairly priced $10 for garage.

Saw Arcade Fire here in April 2014. Loved the arena. The staff was friendly from the time you walked in, and the parking was great in relation to the vicinity of the arena. Great snack food selection at the various kiosks. Highly recommend attending an event here.

title: Lumiere Place Casino, Saint Louis
review_list:
We like to visit this casino, however for my husband and I being non smokers, the smoke level is very heavy. Always a good time, I just wish there was designated smoking areas.

Lumiere Concert venue was cool...the seating is a bit to snug....i felt a bit uncomfortable sitting that close to a total stanger on my left. I wish I could have moved my seat at least 2-3 inches so I wasn't right on his hip & vice versa. bathrooms were clean well lit, acoustics were better than the Pageant to me..I...

Promotions are not tru at all . Played two hours spent $200 and they told me two time I had not played 30 minutes. Casino smokey stuff stuffy. Would not go back even if they sent me $1000 in free play. Over all a crapy time

We went to Lumiere for my birthday/Valentine's Day. Had a great time anyway some money! Only complaint was the heater in our room was loud. They fan was making noise like it was 20 years old and couldn't sleep well. Thank god for the mini bar. I will return.

I went to Lumiere Casino for the first and last time during a recent visit to St. Louis. They were having a special to lure new customers by giving a cash credit after playing for a certain amount of time and earning a certain number of points on the slot machines. All of the machines were in such poor shape;...

Clean, nice with about four eating places, a couple of small shops, preices are average for a casino.Weare not gambling people so we did not gamble any but the machines were busy, Did not see to o many machines lighting up with winners,

Very nice and organized. I did win some and seemed a good place to hang out for a while. The do allow smoking, as with most casinos, but the air recycling made it bearable.

title: Old St. Ferdinand Shrine, Florissant
address: 1 Rue St Francois, Florissant, Saint Louis, MO 63031
review_list:
This beautiful church is a landmark in Florissant. The building is steeped in history. It is beautiful as well.

A beautiful historic church that is a wonderful place to visit! It is a "Must See" for Christians who visit the area and enjoy the history of the Church!

I have only been here once. But if driving thru Florissant, stop by. Florissant itself has seen better days. It use to be a nice, vibrant working class town, but riff raff is sadly moving in.

I have not been inside. I know that they offer tours.
The history of this church and Shrine is very interesting.

True American History..Pierre DeSmet, St. Phillipine Duchesne, Indian school and more! Interesting French heritage. Look at the names on the pews, feel the spirit, visit the bookstore above the old schoolhouse..Walk where explorers and a Saint walked.

Step back in time and look at the old wood work, stained glass windows, fixtures. Old books for sale upstairs. Old wood fired bread baking pit in back. If you like history, you will enjoy a trip here.

The shrine is of significant historical value as it is a part of the French settling of the area. The fact that St. Rose Philippine Dechesne once lived and taught here only adds to the significance. If you are a history buff and are interested in the French history of the St. Louis area, this is a must see.

We appreciated being allowed to look around. The entire place has Catholic relics. It's a little dark inside, but you can see. If you are very excited and interested in Catholic history then you may enjoy this place.
My younger daughter didn't enjoy the tour. She found it creepy.

The Old St. Ferdinand Shrine is full of history. St. Rose Philippine Duchesne lived and worked here. Not many places in the United States can say they were the home of a canonized saint. They have been working hard restoring the Shrine. You must come see it when in the area.

I have visited this site many times in childhood and as an adult. The shrine amazes me and makes me want more recognition of what she contributed to area. It needs help to become an attraction. Most people do not even know it exists. Hours it is open need to be extended. It needs support by the locals and get...

This is definitely a place for much older children or adults. Little kids will be bored out of their minds. It's a beautiful building and the architecture is very impressive, but definitely not going to be fun for younger kids.

review_list:

title: St. Louis City Hall, Saint Louis
review_list:
What a beautiful historic building right in the down area, near the arch. The interior is spectacular with marble, iron railings a fantastic ceiling. If you enjoy old buildings, don't miss this

I enjoy photographing interiors. The Old City Hall features a large lobby/atrium with beautiful marble stairs and railings along with a stunning ceiling. It's worth taking the time to enter the building for this view. To enter, you must pass through security, but the guards were friendly and had no problem with letting me enter with my camera and tripod.

Make a quick stop inside and look for two wall displays. The first will be a memorial to fallen soldiers from WW1. It breaks down how they died including gas attacks. The second tells the story of an ill fated glider demonstration. Worth a look!

This is one of the oldest buildings , looks like no other style building in the saint louis area . Large darker building I could look at it all day . They just dont make buildings like this anymore . Looks like it should be in ancient europe

We went by this building several times during our stay in St. Louis, and my wife could not get over how awesome its appearance was.

i have never had a good experience or a nice worker experience at this place in over 30 years. it will never change. but the building always looks good and so do the floors.

My wife and I stopped at Saint Louis City Hall while walking around in downtown and taking pictures. Unless you are taking pictures or appreciating the architecture, this place is probably not a destination for you. Since it was a Saturday, we did not attempt to go inside.

The exterior is very cool looking. It reminds me of a haunted house. The interior is a bit shabby and rundown looking though.

Its more appealing architecturally than something built in the 70's, but its functions and frustrations are the same for anyone at any city hall anywhere else in the country.
Also, I'm not sure why the only picture here associated with city hall doesn't actually show city hall. That's the old courthouse folks.

If you have to do business here fine but other than being old, there is nothing to really see.

title: West Cabanne Place Historic District, Saint Louis
address: 5900-6100 West Cabanne Place, Saint Louis, MO 63112
review_list:
This is a few streets originally developed as a quiet upper middle class neighborhood in the country away from the city noise. Throughout the 1920's and later the empty countryside was developed. The general area went through a decline around the 1960's. Unfortunately this specific location didn't recover. A small number of original houses remain in various states of condition.

Very lovely row of homes in a not-so-middle-class neighborhood. With the St. Vincent Greenway coming through nearby Ruth Porter Mall, perhaps the West End neighborhood (not to be confused with the Central West End), perhaps things will perk up.

review_list: Interesting place -water colors and photos and oil paintings of local landmarks in St. Louis. Fair prices, nice people and open with food and drink on first fridays, as are all the galleries on Lafayette sq on the first friday of the month. Really liked it.

review_list: Very comfortable and easy to walk thru museum on the campus of St. Louis U. Takes 15-20 minutes to walk thru. Variety of art to look at. Go on the first Friday of the month and it's free.
